column2: Partridge: We Need to Talk About Alan<p>Journalist
column7: vigorous all-rounder – Alan Partridge – a man with a fascinating past and an amazing future. Gregarious and popular
column8: yet Alan’s never happier than when relaxing in his own five-bedroom
column9: south-built house with three acres of land and access to a private stream. But who is this mysterious enigma?</p><p>Alan Gordon Partridge is the best – and best-loved – radio presenter in the region. Born into a changing world of rationing
column11: apes in space and the launch of ITV
column12: Alan’s broadcasting career began as chief DJ of Radio Smile at St. Luke’s Hospital in Norwich. After replacing Peter Flint as the presenter of Scout About
column13: he entered the top 8 of BBC sports presenters.</p><p>But Alan’s big break came with his primetime BBC chat show Knowing Me
column15: the show battled against poor scheduling
column16: having been put up against News at Ten
column17: then in its heyday. Due to declining ratings
column18: a single catastrophic hitch (the killing of a guest on air) and the dumbing down of network TV
column19: Alan’s show was cancelled. Not to be dissuaded
column20: he embraced this opportunity to wind up his production company
column21: leave London and fulfil a lifelong ambition to return to his roots in local radio.</p><p>Now single
column22: Alan is an intensely private man but he opens up
column26: often deeply emotional – and of course compelling – memoir
column27: written entirely in his own words. (Alan quickly dispelled the idea of using a ghost writer. With a grade B English Language O-Level
column28: he knew he was up to the task.)</p><p>He speaks touchingly about his tragic Toblerone addiction
column29: and the painful moment when unsold copies of his first autobiography
column31: were pulped like ‘word porridge’. He reveals all about his relationship with his ex-Ukrainian girlfriend
column33: with whom he had sex at least twice a day
column34: and the truth about the thick people who make key decisions at the BBC.</p><p>A literary tour de force
column36: Partridge: We Need to Talk About Alan charts the incredible journey of one of our greatest broadcasters.</p>Thu

column1: Nomad<p>Narrated by the man himself and written in his unmistakable tone and style
column2: Alan Partridge: Nomad is filled with all the joie de vivre you'd expect.</p><p>In Alan Partridge: Nomad
column4: windcheater and scarf and embarks on an odyssey through a place he once knew - it's called Britain - intent on completing a journey of immense personal significance.</p><p>Diarising his ramble in the form of a 'journey journal'
column5: Alan details the people and places he encounters
column6: ruminates on matters large and small and
column7: on a final leg fraught with danger
column8: becomes not a man (because he was one to start off with) but a better
column9: more inspiring example of a man.</p><p>Through witty vignettes
column10: heavy essays and nod-inducing pieces of wisdom
column11: Alan shines a light on the nooks of the nation and the crannies of himself
column12: making this a biography that biographs the biographer while also biographing bits of Britain.</p>Thu

column1: From the Oasthouse - S01<p>From the Oasthouse – Series 1</p><p>Broadcaster
column3: philanthroper and one of the first public figures to suggest high-visibility clothing for people manning temporary car parks
column4: the public Alan Partridge is a cherished institution.</p><p>But what of the unseen Alan?</p><p>For the first time
column5: this famously private man welcomes us into his home and audibly deshrouds himself for a fascinating series of podcasts. Over the course of 18 generously durated episodes
column6: Partridge grants us full and unfettered access to his off-screen life (within reason).</p><p>In exchange for a series of payments from Audible
column7: he promises an access-all-areas pass to the nooks and crannies of his hinterland
column10: more reflective Alan than many of his more vaunted peers have given him credit for. He then sends the resultant podcasts to Audible ensuring they meet the technical specifications laid down in the contract.</p>Thu

column1: From The Oasthouse – S02E01 Rekindlings<p>From the Oasthouse – Series 2 – Episode 1</p><p>Alan returns to podcasting
column2: offering his unique perspective on life’s big questions
column3: the hot-button issues of the day
column4: his professional successes and the most intimate details of his personal life in a series he is already calling ‘seminal’. The second series will come partly from the oasthouse—in order to satisfy people who'd rather he didn’t mess with the format—and partly from other locations—to appeal to those who found the original format a bit limiting.</p>Thu

column1: From the Oasthouse - S03<p>From the Oasthouse – Series 3</p><p>Few humans in the history of civilisation have had a third series of their podcast commissioned. Fewer still have produced one that’s actually any good. Partridge Gordon Alan
column2: or Alan Gordon Partridge to write his name the correct way round
column3: is one of them.</p><p>Now as comfortable at the controls of a podcast as he is driving all cars and doing most swimming strokes
column4: Alan returns with a series that whooshes and pinballs around the many areas (there are approximately nine) of his life and brain. And with no regular
column5: contracted broadcasting work to clutter up his days
column6: Alan is free to focus on matters closer to home. Still based at his quasi-rural oasthouse
column7: which now boasts a significantly better kettle than in series one and two
column10: hopes and dreams spread across eleven episodes with a mean duration of the twenty minutes stipulated in the contract. Would a better approach have been to let the content of each episode dictate its length? Of course it would but that’s a discussion for another day.</p><p>So join Alan as he tackles the green eyed monster of envy in his attempts to keep hold of his new love
column11: as he navigates how to re-invigorate an increasingly distracted personal assistant
column12: as he vies for one of the most sought-after car-related ambassadorial positions in all of east Anglia
column13: and as he seeks to track down an old Geordie friend long-presumed dead.</p><p>They say there’s nothing more boring than the mundanities of everyday life. Well
column14: Alan’s podcast focuses on literally nothing else. We hope you enjoy it.</p>Thu

column2: Norwich's favourite son and best broadcaster
column4: triumphs against the odds. TWICE.</strong></p><p>Using an innovative 'dual narrative' structure you sometimes see in films
column5: Big Beacon tells the story of how Partridge heroically rebuilt his TV career
column6: rising like a phoenix from the desolate wasteland of local radio to climb to the summit of Mount Primetime and regain the nationwide prominence his talent merits.</p><p>But then something quite unexpected and moving
column7: because Big Beacon also tells the story of a selfless man
column8: driven to restore an old lighthouse to its former glory
column9: motivated by nothing more than respect for a quietly heroic old building that many take for granted
column10: which some people think is a metaphor for Alan himself even though it's not really for them to say.*</p><p>Leaving his old life behind and relocating to a small coastal village in Kent
column12: wins the hearts and minds of a suspicious community
column13: and ultimately shows himself to be a quite wonderful man.</p><p>* The two strands will run in tandem
column14: their narrative arcs mirroring each other to make the parallels between the two stories abundantly clear to the less able reader.</p>Thu
